mesquite.lib

Class MesquiteNumber

  • java.lang.Object
    • mesquite.lib.MesquiteNumber
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Listable, WithStringDetails

    public class MesquiteNumber
extends java.lang.Object
implements Listable, WithStringDetails
    This class is used to store numbers flexibly, so that system doesn't need to know whether int, long or double. Automatically upgrades calculations to use long or double as needed. Because they have the overhead of objects, it is best to avoid their wanton proliferation. If an array is needed, better to use the NumberArray, which behaves similarly but stores the data as a primitive type arrays. Most of the methods in MesquiteNumber use the incoming parameter as a guide to how the data should be stored. Thus there are int, long, and double versions of many methods. Calculations involving mixed types automatically upgrade the storage to the bigger type.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(int value,
                      boolean mustBeCombinable)
        Determines if current value equals passed value. If "mustBeCombinable" is true, then returns false if either current value or passed value are not combinable. Otherwise, returns true if the stored values are identical

      • checkMinMax

        public static void checkMinMax(MesquiteBoolean first,
                               MesquiteNumber min,
                               MesquiteNumber max,
                               MesquiteNumber value)
        Checks to see if the number value is less than min (in which case min is reset) or greater than max (in which case max is reset). If it is the first time this function is called for this particular use, the values of min and max are set to the value .

        public void setToFirstScaleMark(MesquiteNumber min,
                                MesquiteNumber max,
                                int minTicks)
        For a ruler or marked scale that is with start point at min, end at max, and at least minTicks marks, what is first scale mark?

      • setToScaleIncrement

        public void setToScaleIncrement(MesquiteNumber min,
                                MesquiteNumber max,
                                int minTicks)
        For a ruler or marked scale that is with start point at min, end at max, and at least minTicks marks, what is increment between ticks?

      • setWithinBounds

        public int setWithinBounds(MesquiteNumber min,
                           MesquiteNumber max,
                           int numUnits)
        this method is used to return the object's value as an integer between 0 and numUnits, scaling it according to its position between min and max's values. This is useful for graphing and so on, since the graphing program doesn't have to know the data types of this object, min or max in order to calculate the appropriate pixel placement in a graph, for instance

      • getUnboundedValue

        public double getUnboundedValue(MesquiteNumber min,
                                MesquiteNumber max,
                                int numUnits)
        this method does the inverse of setWithinBounds.

      • findWithinBounds

        public void findWithinBounds(MesquiteNumber min,
                             MesquiteNumber max,
                             int value,
                             int bound)
        this method is used to set the object's value according to value, a number between 0 and bound, so that the difference between min and max is scaled to bound

      • findInterval

        public int findInterval(MesquiteNumber min,
                        MesquiteNumber max,
                        int numIntervals)
        this method is returns which interval the value occurs in, if the given range is cut into the given number of intervals. This is useful for graphing histograms that group into intervals.

      • findInterval

        public int findInterval(MesquiteNumber min,
                        MesquiteNumber unit)
        this method is returns which interval the value occurs in, if the given range is cut into intervals of width "unit". This is useful for graphing histograms that group into intervals.
